Linguistic covariation and coherence

Overview

Covariation and coherence

How do linguistic variables work together?

How do speakers cluster w.r.t. multiple variables?

Do speakers pattern in the same way across the lifespan?

Are styles, lects, registers, personae, characterised
by collections of covarying variables?

Aim: suggest some actual research interest rather than just methods.

This session

Quantitative methods for exploring covariation of linguistic variables.

Garden paths

  • Clustering methods can find clusters in random data
  • Epistemic issues in research applying machine learning are relevant.
  • Fears of a new replication crisis (see, e.g., Kapoor and Narayanan 2022)
  • Careful application is necessary!
  • Value in focusing on methods.

Aim: raise the importance of using clustering and covariation methods carefully and with our brains turned on.

Methods

PCA

  • PCA: Principal Component Analysis
  • Finds (usually interpretable) structure in continuous multivariate data.
  • e.g.: Patterns in vocalic formant readings.
    • Do certain vowels tend to move together?
    • Do speakers cluster with respect to covarying vowels?

Points to hit:

  • Basic patter about the data.
    • Speaker means from ONZE (100 random speakers)
    • Scaled across speaker (as typically done by PCA functions)
    • DRESS + TRAP go down together, while KIT goes up.
  • Start with cloud of points.
  • Find the centre.
  • Find the line which goes through the cloud for the longest.
    • i.e. this is the line through the centre of the cloud which maxmimises variance.
  • Now find the line at right angles to the first line, which goes through the cloud for the longest. etc. etc.
  • Typically, there are many more dimensions than three, so we lose the ability to visualise the whole process.

What is PCA?

  1. Find the centre of the cloud.
  2. Draw the line through the centre which stays in the cloud for the longest.
    • i.e. the line which maximises variance.
  3. Draw the line through the centre which stays in the cloud for the longest and is a right angles to the previous lines.
  4. Repeat (3) until you run out of dimensions.

So to repeat:

The point of this slide is to quickly summarise what youve talked through with the animation.

Interpretable pattern: PC1: speakers with high values, tend to have high values across the board e.g. by having smaller vocal tracts. PC2: speaker with high DRESS, tend to also have high TRAP and low KIT, all else being equal.

Loadings and Scores

  • Original variables have loadings for each PC.
  • Loadings tell us the relationship between PCs and original variables.
    • e.g.: increase in PC2 = decrease in kit and increase in dress and trap
  • Each speaker has a score for each PC.
  • Scores tell us where speakers sit given the PCs.
    • e.g.: a high PC2 score means a conservative NZE speaker.
  • Describe the relationship between the original variables and PCA.
  • Define loadings.

Define scores. Show how speakers are plotted with respect to PCs.

Note that this plot shows speakers with respect to clusters of variables.

PCA and friends

  • Key question: what do we put in to PCA?
    • Raw data.
    • Model predictions (incl. CCA: Constrained Correspondence Analysis)
      • i.e., the variation explained by identified predictors
      • see Hurring (12:15) and Walker (1:45).
    • Random intercepts or residuals (e.g. Brand et al. 2021)
      • i.e., the variation not explained by identified predictors.
      • see Hurring (12:15). Wilson Black and Sheard (11:45).
  • Key question: What do we do after PCA?
    • e.g.: compare size of rectangles containing groups in PC space (Beaman and Sering 2022)
  • A lot of methods are relatives of PCA.
  • Set out the family in terms of what you put in to PCA and what you do with the output.
  • Connect to specific presentations in the session.
  • Ill mention that many people working in this area couldnt make it.

MDS

  • Pairwise differences a multidimensial space.
    • e.g. perceptual judgments of similarity.
    • e.g. difference measures derived from production data.
  • Like PCA: speakers can be clustered in a continuous space.
  • Additional methods are needed to explain the dimensions.
  • Sheard et al. (11:15) use MDS to explore the factors driving perceptual similarity judgments.
  • Research question: are known vowel patterns in NZE socially salient to listeners?

Tree methods

  • Clustering algorithms can (often) be represented by trees.
  • Divisive clustering starts with one cluster, then successively breaks off objects into new clusters.
  • These breaks form a tree.

This and the following plots will show what clustering with a tree looks like using the PC scores Ive already plotted.

Tree methods (cont.)

  • Tree-based clustering is very flexible.
  • Choosing the number of clusters can be difficult
  • Travis and Qiao (2:15) cluster linguistic variables in order to group speakers.
  • Upshot: an alternative to starting with social classifications and then turning to linguistic behaviour.
  • Other tree methods split by a single variable.
  • Sheard et al. (11:15) use regression trees to interpret MDS results.

Hopes

Hopes

  • Increased sharing of methods.
  • Cross pollination.
  • Emergence of new methods.
  • Increased use of open science practices.
  • Hearing about alternatives from you.

Aim: express a few hopes for the session.
